378.title: Theft
378.legal_text: Whoever, intending to take dishonestly any movable property out of the possession of any person without that person's consent, moves that property in order to such taking, is said to commit theft.
378.nature:
Definition (Punished under 379)
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
378.practical_explanation: Taking someone else's movable property without their permission dishonestly.
378.example: Pickpocketing a wallet from someone's pocket.

379.title: Punishment for theft
379.legal_text: Whoever commits theft shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
379.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
379.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Compoundable (value < 2000 or with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate

380.title: Theft in dwelling house, etc.
380.legal_text: Theft in any building, tent or vessel, which building, tent or vessel is used as a human dwelling, or used for the custody of property.
380.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
380.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
380.practical_explanation: Stealing from inside a house or building used for storage/living.
380.example: Burglar entering a home and stealing jewelry.
380.conclusion: More serious than simple theft due to violation of dwelling.

383.title: Extortion
383.legal_text: Whoever intentionally puts any person in fear of any injury to that person, or to any other, and thereby dishonestly induces the person so put in fear to deliver to any person any property.
383.nature:
Definition (Punished under 384)
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
383.practical_explanation: Forcing someone to give money or property by threatening them.
383.example: Threatening to publish compromising photos unless paid money.

384.title: Punishment for extortion
384.legal_text: Whoever commits extortion shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
384.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
384.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
384.example: Blackmailing a shopkeeper for protection money.

390.title: Robbery
390.legal_text: In all robbery there is either theft or extortion. Theft is 'robbery' if, in order to the committing of the theft, or in committing the theft, or in carrying away or attempting to carry away property obtained by the theft, the offender, for that end, voluntarily causes or attempts to cause to any person death or hurt or wrongful restraint.
390.nature:
Definition (Punished under 392)
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
390.practical_explanation: Theft or extortion involving immediate violence or threat of death/hurt.
390.example: Holding a knife to someone's throat to steal their watch.
390.conclusion: Robbery is an aggravated form of theft/extortion.

392.title: Punishment for robbery
392.legal_text: Whoever commits robbery shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
392.punishment: Imprisonment up to 10 years (14 years if on highway between sunset and sunrise) and fine
392.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class

395.title: Punishment for dacoity
395.legal_text: Whoever commits dacoity shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
395.punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine
395.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session
395.practical_explanation: Robbery committed by 5 or more people working together.
395.conclusion: One of the most serious property crimes.

403.title: Dishonest misappropriation of property
403.legal_text: Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use any movable property.
403.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
403.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
403.practical_explanation: Keeping found property or using someone else's property for yourself dishonestly.
403.example: Finding a gold ring and selling it instead of finding the owner.

405.title: Criminal breach of trust
405.legal_text: Whoever, being in any manner entrusted with property, dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use that property.
405.nature:
Definition (Punished under 406)
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
405.practical_explanation: Betraying trust regarding money or property entrusted to you.
405.example: An employee using company funds for personal vacation.

406.title: Punishment for criminal breach of trust
406.legal_text: Whoever commits criminal breach of trust shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
406.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
406.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
406.practical_explanation: Penalty for violating trust with property.
406.example: A cashier stealing money from the till.

415.title: Cheating
415.legal_text: Whoever, by deceiving any person, fraudulently or dishonestly induces the person so deceived to deliver any property... constitutes cheating.
415.nature:
Definition (Punished under 417)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
415.practical_explanation: Deceiving someone to get them to do something or give something.
415.example: Selling a fake watch claiming it is real.

417.title: Punishment for cheating
417.legal_text: Whoever cheats shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
417.punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both
417.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
417.example: Lying about a product feature to make a sale.

420.title: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property
420.legal_text: Whoever cheats and thereby dishonestly induces the person deceived to deliver any property to any person... shall be punished.
420.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
420.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
420.practical_explanation: Serious fraud where property is obtained by deception. The famous '420' offence.
420.example: Taking money for a job promise and disappearing.
next_steps: Prepare evidence of lack of intent.
420.conclusion: The primary section for serious fraud and con-artistry.

425.title: Mischief
425.legal_text: Whoever with intent to cause, or knowing that he is likely to cause, wrongful loss or damage to the public or to any person, causes the destruction of any property...
425.nature:
Definition (Punished under 426)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate

426.title: Punishment for mischief
426.legal_text: Whoever commits mischief shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine, or with both.
426.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine, or both
426.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate

441.title: Criminal trespass
441.legal_text: Whoever enters into or upon property in the possession of another with intent to commit an offence or to intimidate, insult or annoy any person in possession of such property...
441.nature:
Definition (Punished under 447)
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
441.practical_explanation: Entering someone's property without permission to cause trouble.
441.example: Entering a neighbor's garden to threaten them.

447.title: Punishment for criminal trespass
447.legal_text: Whoever commits criminal trespass shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine, or with both.
447.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine, or both
447.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate

448.title: Punishment for house-trespass
448.legal_text: Whoever commits house-trespass shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
448.punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both
448.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
448.practical_explanation: Entering a house or building illegally.
448.example: Entering someone's home without invitation to argue.

463.title: Forgery
463.legal_text: Whoever makes any false documents or false electronic record or part of a document or electronic record, with intent to cause damage or injury...
463.nature:
Definition (Punished under 465)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
463.example: Signing someone else's name on a check.

464.title: Making a false document
464.legal_text: A person is said to make a false document or false electronic record...
464.practical_explanation: The act of creating the fake part of a document.
464.example: Altering a date on a contract.

465.title: Punishment for forgery
465.legal_text: Whoever commits forgery shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
465.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
465.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class

468.title: Forgery for purpose of cheating
468.legal_text: Whoever commits forgery, intending that the document or electronic record forged shall be used for the purpose of cheating.
468.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
468.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
468.practical_explanation: Forging a document specifically to cheat someone out of money/property.
468.example: Forging a property deed to sell land that isn't yours.

471.title: Using as genuine a forged document or electronic record
471.legal_text: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly uses as genuine any document or electronic record which he knows or has reason to believe to be a forged document.
471.punishment: Same as if he had forged it (Section 465 or 468)
471.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
471.practical_explanation: Using a fake document knowing it is fake.
471.example: Submitting a fake marksheet for a job application.
471.conclusion: Using a forgery is as bad as making one.

498A.title: Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty
498A.legal_text: Whoever, being the husband or the relative of the husband of a woman, subjects such woman to cruelty shall be punished.
498A.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years and fine
498A.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
498A.practical_explanation: Cruelty (physical or mental) by husband or in-laws, often related to dowry.
498A.example: Harassing a wife for not bringing enough dowry.
498A.conclusion: Specific law to protect married women from cruelty.

499.title: Defamation
499.legal_text: Whoever, by words either spoken or intended to be read... makes or publishes any imputation concerning any person intending to harm... the reputation of such person.
499.nature:
Definition (Punished under 500)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
499.practical_explanation: Damaging someone's reputation via speech or writing.
499.example: Writing a false article claiming someone is a thief.

500.title: Punishment for defamation
500.legal_text: Whoever defames another shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
500.punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
500.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class

503.title: Criminal intimidation
503.legal_text: Whoever threatens another with any injury to his person, reputation or property... with intent to cause alarm to that person.
503.nature:
Definition (Punished under 506)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
503.practical_explanation: Threatening someone to frighten them or make them do something.
503.example: Threatening to beat someone up if they don't withdraw a complaint.

504.title: Intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace
504.legal_text: Whoever intentionally insults, and thereby gives provocation to any person, intending or knowing it to be likely that such provocation will cause him to break the public peace.
504.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
504.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
504.practical_explanation: Abusing someone firmly to provoke a fight.
504.example: Using abusive language in a public argument.

506.title: Punishment for criminal intimidation
506.legal_text: Whoever commits the offence of criminal intimidation shall be punished... If threat be to cause death or grievous hurt, etc.
506.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years (Simple); Up to 7 years (Aggravated - death threat)
506.nature:
Part 1: Non-cognizable / Bailable
Part 2 (Death threat): Cognizable / Non-bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
506.practical_explanation: Punishment for threatening someone. Severity depends on the threat (e.g. death threat is serious).

509.title: Word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman
509.legal_text: Whoever, intending to insult the modesty of any woman, utters any word, makes any sound or gesture, or exhibits any object...
509.punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 3 years and fine
509.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
509.practical_explanation: Verbal or gestural harassment of a woman.
509.example: Making lewd comments or gestures at a woman.

511.title: Punishment for attempting to commit offences punishable with imprisonment for life or other imprisonment
511.legal_text: Whoever attempts to commit an offence punishable by this Code with imprisonment for life or imprisonment... and in such attempt does any act towards the commission of the offence.
511.punishment: Up to half the imprisonment term of the main offence
511.nature:
Same as the offence attempted (usually)
Cognizable / Bailable (varies)
Triable by court triable for main offence
511.practical_explanation: If you try to commit a crime but fail, you can still be punished for the attempt.
511.example: Checking a pocket to steal property but finding it empty (Attempt to theft).
511.conclusion: General provision for punishment of attempts.

279.title: Rash driving or riding on a public way
279.legal_text: Whoever drives any vehicle, or rides, on any public way in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life...
279.punishment: Imprisonment up to 6 months, or fine up to 1000 rupees, or both
279.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
next_steps: Appear in court if summons received.

304A.title: Causing death by negligence
304A.legal_text: Whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide.
304A.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
304A.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
304A.practical_explanation: Accidental death caused by carelessness (e.g. road accident).

304B.title: Dowry death
304B.legal_text: Where the death of a woman is caused by any burns or bodily injury or occurs otherwise than under normal circumstances within seven years of her marriage...
304B.punishment: Imprisonment for not less than 7 years but which may extend to life
304B.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session
304B.practical_explanation: Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage due to harassment for dowry.
304B.example: Bride burning or suicide due to dowry demands.
